sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• discontinue gradually to reduce risk of increased seizure frequency and status epilepticus
  • Partial seizure; Adjunct: initial, 400 mg ORALLY once daily for 1 week; may initiate treatment at 800 mg ORALLY once daily if need for seizure reduction outweighs increased risk of adverse reactions during initiation
  • Partial seizure; Adjunct: maintenance, 800 mg ORALLY once daily; may increase to MAX of 1200 mg ORALLY once daily after 1 week, but adverse reactions may be increased at this dosage

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients younger than 18 years

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment, CrCl less than 50 mL/min: initial dose, 200 mg ORALLY once daily for 2 weeks followed by maintenance dose of 400 mg ORALLY once daily; maximum recommended maintenance dosage of 600 mg orally once daily may benefit some patients
  • hepatic impairment, mild to moderate: no dose adjustment required
  • hepatic impairment, severe: use not recommended
  • adjunctive therapy with oxcarbazepine: use not recommended
  • adjunctive therapy with carbamazepine: dose adjustment of eslicarbazepine or carbamazepine may be needed for efficacy or tolerability
  • adjunctive therapy with other enzyme-inducing antiepileptic drugs (ie, phenobarbital, phenytoin, primidone): dosage of eslicarbazepine may need to be increased
  • gender: no dosage adjustments needed

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to eslicarbazepine acetate, oxcarbazepine, or any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• abrupt discontinuation may increase seizure frequency; withdraw gradually
  • anaphylaxis and angioedema have been reported; discontinue use if occur
  • dermatological reactions, serious (eg, Stevens-Johnson syndrome), have been reported; discontinue use unless clearly not drug related; do not initiate therapy if previous dermatologic reaction has occurred while on eslicarbazepine or oxcarbazepine
  • drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) (ie, multiorgan hypersensitivity), potentially fatal, has been reported; discontinue and do not resume use if occurs and an alternative etiology cannot be determined; do not initiate therapy if previous DRESS has occurred while on eslicarbazepine or oxcarbazepine
  • hepatic injury (elevated transaminases and bilirubin) has been reported; monitoring recommended; discontinue use if jaundice or laboratory evidence of significant liver injury occurs
  • hepatic impairment, severe; use not recommended
  • hyponatremia has been reported; increased risk with increasing dose or concomitant hyponatremia-inducing drugs; consider monitoring; dose reduction and/or discontinuation may be necessary
  • neurologic events, dose-dependent (eg, dizziness, gait, coordination, cognitive and visual disturbances, fatigue, and somnolence) have been reported; increased risk with large doses, during titration, elderly (60 years or older), and concomitant carbamazepine
  • renal impairment, moderate and severe (CrCl less than 50 mL/min); dose adjustment required
  • suicidal ideation and behavior have been reported with antiepileptic active substances; monitoring recommended
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (10% to 16%), Vomiting (6% to 10%)
  • Neurologic:Ataxia (4% to 6%), Dizziness (20% to 28%), Headache (13% to 15%), Somnolence (11% to 18%), Tremor (2% to 4%), Vertigo (2% to 6%)
  • Ophthalmic:Blurred vision (5% to 6%), Diplopia (9% to 11%)
  • Other:Fatigue (4% to 7%)
Serious
  • Hematologic:Drug-induced eosinophilia
  • Hepatic:Increased liver enzymes, Serum bilirubin raised
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis, Drug hypersensitivity syndrome
  • Psychiatric:Suicidal thoughts
  • Other:Angioedema

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Eslicarbazepine acetate is a prodrug metabolized to eslicarbazepine, an anticonvulsant, which is thought to inhibit voltage-gated sodium channels.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, oral: 1 to 4 hours
  • Bioavailability, oral: highly
  • Effects of food: no effect

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Intestinal Wall, Liver: 91% via first-pass
  • Eslicarbazepine (major): active
  • (R)-licarbazepine and oxcarbazepine (minor): active
  • moderate inhibitor of CYP2C19
  • inducer of CYP3A4

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Renal: more than 90% as eslicarbazepine and glucuronide metabolites
  • Renal clearance: 20 mL/min
  • Dialyzable: Yes, partial removal via hemodialysis

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • may be administered as whole tablets or crushed tablets
  • may be administered with or without food

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• reduction in seizure frequency is indicative of efficacy
  • serum sodium and chloride levels, especially in patients using concomitant drugs that decrease serum sodium levels; during maintenance therapy
  • liver laboratory tests at baseline
  • neurological events, including gait and coordination disturbances, nystagmus, balance, and ataxia
  • new or worsening of depression, suicidal thoughts or behavior, or unusual changes in mood or behavior

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Patient should avoid activities requiring mental alertness or coordination until drug effects are realized.
  • This drug may decrease effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives with concurrent use. Recommend additional form of barrier birth control during treatment and for at least 1 menstrual cycle after treatment has been discontinued.
  • Side effects may include dizziness, headache, diplopia, vomiting, vertigo, ataxia, blurred vision, and tremor.
  • Instruct patient, caregivers, and families to report worsening depression, suicidal ideation, or unusual changes in behavior.
  • Advise patient to report signs/symptoms of serious skin reactions, including Stevens-Johnson syndrome (flu-like symptoms, spreading red rash, or skin/mucous membrane blistering) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (widespread peeling/blistering of skin).
  • Instruct patient to report fever associated with symptoms of other organ/system involvement (eg, rash, lymphadenopathy, hepatic dysfunction).
  • Advise patient to report symptoms of anaphylaxis or angioedema (swelling of the face, eyes, lips, tongue, or difficulty in swallowing or breathing).
  • Instruct patient to report symptoms of low sodium (eg, nausea, tiredness, lack of energy, irritability, confusion, muscle weakness or spasms, or more frequent or more severe seizures).
  • Advise patient to report symptoms of liver injury (eg, jaundice)
  • Advise patient against sudden discontinuation of drug.
